parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build the CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find.

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand the methodology and precision required for this research. Please provide the first software tool you would like me to investigate.

Understood. I will conduct a comprehensive search for all mentions of the software tool "Archeofrag" from 1995 onwards. This includes:
- Checking version control repositories for code with commit dates.
- Reviewing scholarly literature for published references.
- Searching blog posts, about pages, and any other web mentions.
- Ensuring each source is recorded in the CSV format as per your specifications, with one row per mention.

I'll let you know once I have gathered the data.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a comprehensive search for all mentions of the software tool "Archeofrag" from 1995 onwards. This includes:
- Checking version control repositories for code with commit dates.
- Reviewing scholarly literature for published references.
- Searching blog posts, about pages, and any other web mentions.
- Ensuring each source is recorded in the CSV format as per your specifications, with one row per mention.

I'll let you know once I have gathered the data.","title":"Comprehensive Evidence Collection for Archeofrag","prompt":"Conduct a thorough search for all mentions of the archaeology-related software tool "Archeofrag" from 1995 onwards. Collect data systematically by:

- Searching for published version control repositories with commit dates.
- Identifying scholarly literature that references Archeofrag.
- Reviewing blog posts, project pages, and other web mentions.
- Ensuring that every mention is recorded in the CSV format as follows:

```
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"
```

Each valid source should be recorded in a separate row, ensuring precision in data collection. If the date is unavailable, mark it as "n.d.". Any uncertainties regarding provenance or data quality should be noted under "AI Notes." Explore adjacent years systematically if a date is found.

Provide a detailed CSV with all the data you collect."}

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a thorough search for all mentions of the archaeology-related software tool "Archeofrag" from 1995 onwards. Collect data systematically by:

- Searching for published version control repositories with commit dates.
- Identifying scholarly literature that references Archeofrag.
- Reviewing blog posts, project pages, and other web mentions.
- Ensuring that every mention is recorded in the CSV format as follows:

```
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"
```

Each valid source should be recorded in a separate row, ensuring precision in data collection. If the date is unavailable, mark it as "n.d.". Any uncertainties regarding provenance or data quality should be noted under "AI Notes." Explore adjacent years systematically if a date is found.

Provide a detailed CSV with all the data you collect.

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"Archeofrag","2020","Zenodo Software Archive (v0.6.1)","https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4294066","Initial archived release of Archeofrag (version 0.6.1) on Zenodo, published November 27, 2020【39†L15-L23】"
"Archeofrag","n.d.","Open-Archaeo Software List","https://open-archaeo.info/post/archeofrag/","Listing on the Open-Archaeo site for open-source archaeological software (undated; entry captured in an archive dated Nov 30, 2020)【6†L86-L94】"
"Archeofrag","2021","Journal of Archaeological Science (JAS)","https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jas.2021.105501","Peer-reviewed article introducing the TSAR method; the Archeofrag R package is mentioned as the implementation of this method【46†L313-L321】【46†L323-L324】"
"Archeofrag","2022","Bulletin de la Société préhistorique française","http://www.prehistoire.org/offres/doc_inline_src/515/0-BSPF_2022_1_2e_partie_Correspondance_PLUTNIAK.pdf","Short correspondence (in French) on the TSAR method and the Archeofrag package, published in BSPF vol. 119(1) pages 110–113【15†L3-L7】"
"Archeofrag","2022","Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS)","https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.04335","Open-source software paper describing Archeofrag (submitted Feb 17, 2022; published Jul 31, 2022)【2†L13-L16】【2†L30-L37】"
"Archeofrag","2022","Rzine (R community e-zine)","https://rzine.fr/ressources/20220811_archeofrag_joss/","French-language article in Rzine announcing the JOSS publication of Archeofrag【63†L153-L161】【63†L155-L158】"
"Archeofrag","2023","Advances in Archaeological Practice (ArchaeoSRP article)","https://doi.org/10.1017/aap.2023.22","Paper introducing the ArchaeoSRP package (vol. 11, issue 4) cites Archeofrag (Plutniak 2022) as an example of an archaeological spatial analysis tool【65†L463-L470】【67†L1-L4】"
"Archeofrag","2023","Edited Volume Chapter (Routledge)","https://doi.org/10.4324/9781003350026-10","Book chapter “Four Problems for Archaeological Fragmentation Studies...” (Routledge, 2023) applies the TSAR method using Archeofrag (Neolithic pottery case study)【9†L332-L339】"
"Archeofrag","2024","Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN)","https://cran.r-project.org/package=archeofrag","Official CRAN release of Archeofrag version 1.0.0 (publication date 2024-12-17)【1†L23-L30】"
```
